g.text: As mentioned above, the steric demands of all three
phosphines used in the present work are essentially the same
steric eﬀects are not expected to play a signiﬁcant role in the
outcome of the cation exchange reactions. However, Tolman
cone angles are just a ﬁrst approximation as they do not take
into account the eﬀect of diﬀerent M
diﬀerent metal centers, and the overall interaction with other
ligands coordinated to the same metal center.
actual cone angles obtained from X-ray structural data (the so-
called solid cone angles) typically deviate from the Tolman
cone angles, varying over a wide range depending on the
nature of the metal center and bond length (shorter bonds
angles determined for triphenylphosphine complexes range
whereas the Tolman cone angle of
In the case of Ni complexes, a
slightly larger solid cone angle has been reported for TPP with
consistent with the bulkier nature of the former (containing
three phenyl groups) with respect to the latter (which contains
only two phenyl groups). If the impact of steric eﬀects on the
outcome of the cation exchange reactions were signiﬁcant, one
would expect a diﬀerence between the reactivity of the
complexes using TPP and DPP as ligands, in contrast with our
experimental data, which show that GaCl
DPP have similar reactivities. This implies that the kinetics of
the cation exchange reactions studied in our work are primarily
dictated by the electronic properties of the phosphine ligands
the geometry of the activated Cu
forms at the surface of the Cu
S NC at the onset of the
cation exchange reaction. After the place exchange between the
the two chlorides still bound to the incorporated Ga
will react with two neighboring Cu
from the NC surface as neutral CuCl units, which are highly
soluble in the apolar reaction medium used in our experiments
c, step 4). This likely increases the thermodynamic
driving force of the overall CE reaction both entropically and
enthalpically as two more chemical species are released in
further promote the CE reaction by allowing more Cu
to diﬀuse to the surface, while allowing the incorporated Ga
guest cation to diﬀuse inward. As previously shown for CE
reactions in copper chalcogenide NCs, the CE rates increase
To illustrate the general applicability of the ﬁndings presented
parent CIS NCs have an indium-rich composition with a Cu/
0.008:1. EDS analysis of the product NCs
ratios imply that the charge balance is preserved through the
CE reaction, as the relative concentration of Ga ions multiplied
by their charge of +3 exactly corresponds to the decrease in Cu
the CIS NCs are preserved in the product CIGS NCs (see
a,d), despite the removal of a signiﬁcant amount of
cations from the NC. Fast Fourier transform (FFT) analysis of
the high-resolution TEM images allows determination of the
lattice spacings, being 0.18, 0.21, and 0.34 nm before and after
, they are not signiﬁcantly changed by the CE
reaction). However, analysis of the ED patterns shows a shift
e), indicating a small contraction of
the unit cell. This contraction is consistent with the exchange
The optical properties of the template CIS NCs and the
product Ga-containing (CIGS) NCs are shown in
g) spectra show a blue shift after the CE reaction,
indicating a widening of the band gap. This can be attributed
to either an increase in quantum conﬁnement due to a smaller
cation exchange in luminescent CIS NCs.
(a) High-resolution TEM image of the parent CIS NCs. The inset
shows the FFT of the image. (b) High-resolution TEM image of
the product CIGS NCs after reaction; the inset shows the FFT of
the image. (c,d) Enlarged TEMimage of single NCs before (c) and
FFTs. Both scale bars correspond to 5 nm. (e) Azimuthally
integrated ED patterns of the parent CIS NCs and product CIGS
NCs, and bulk roquesite CIS X-ray diﬀraction reference pattern
spectra of the parent CIS NCs and product CIGS NCs. The inset
in (f) shows the normalized absorption spectra. The PL quantum
yield of the product CIGS NCs is at least 10 times higher than that
of the parent CIS NCs. The dip in the PL spectrum around 1150
nm is caused by absorption of emitted light by toluene, which was
